title: Faith, Agnosticism and the Limits of Human Reason
sub_head: In matters of belief about God, we do not and cannot know.
body:
As a former minister turned agnostic, I enjoyed reading “Why Atheists Need Faith” (Houses of Worship, Sept. 24) by Michael Guillen, a scientist and former atheist turned Christian. Just as Mr. Guillen arrived at Christianity during his doctoral studies by debunking core tenets of his atheistic worldview, I left Christianity by studying the New Testament, not through the lens of faith, but in graduate and postgraduate settings through the lens of the historical-critical method of biblical scholarship. It raises questions about the authorship and authenticity of scripture.
For me, the paucity of extrabiblical evidence for even the existence of Jesus, let alone the historical-critical problems with his alleged resurrection, led me to abandon my faith (and career as a Baptist minister), a faith that had been foundational since childhood.
